details.title: Solving the Redundancy Allocation Problem With a Mix of Components Using the Improved Surrogate Constraint Method

p: Junichi Onishi received his B.S. and M.S. degrees from Kansai University, Japan in 2003, and 2005, respectively. He is currently working as a System Engineer at Hitachi, Ltd. His research interests are in reliability optimization, and meta-heuristics. He is a member of the Institute of Electrics, Information and Communication Engineers.

Sakuo Kimura received his B.S., M.S., and PhD degrees from Kansai University, Japan. He is a director of Takatsuki Campus Office of Kansai University. His current research interests include reliability optimization, and mathematical programming. He is a member of the Institute of Electrics, Information, and Communication Engineers, of the Operation Research Society of Japan, of the Japan Industrial Management Association, and of the Information Processing Society of Japan.

Ross J. W. James received his BMS (Honours), and PhD degrees from the University of Waikato, New Zealand. In 1995, he joined the University of Canterbury. Currently he is a senior lecturer in the Management Science Group within the Department of Management. His current research interests include scheduling systems, meta-heuristics, learning systems, and algorithm development and implementation.

Yuji Nakagawa received the B.SE. in Electronics Engineering from the Himeji Institute of Technology, Japan 1973, and the D.E. from Kyoto University, Japan in 1979. He is a Professor in Faculty of Informatics, Kansai University, Japan. His research interests are in reliability optimization, sort and search algorithms, and mathematical programming. He is a member of IEEE, of the Institute of Electrics, Information, and Communication Engineers, of the Operation Research Society of Japan, and of the Japan Industrial Management Association.

details.abstract: When designing a system, there are two methods that can be used to improve the system's reliability without changing the nature of the system: 1) using more reliable components, and/or 2) providing redundant components within the system. The redundancy allocation problem attempts to find the appropriate mix of components & redundancies within a system in order to either minimize cost subject to a minimum level of reliability, or maximize reliability subject to a maximum cost and weight. Redundancy allocation problems can be classified into two groups; one allows the system to have a mix of components with different characteristics incorporated in the system, while the other only allows one type of each component. The former group has a much larger solution space compared to the latter, and therefore obtaining an exact optimal or even a high quality solution for this problem may be more difficult. Optimization techniques, based on meta-heuristic approaches, have recently been proposed to solve the redundancy allocation problem with a mix of components. However, an exact solution method has not been developed. In this paper, we develop an exact solution method, based on the improved surrogate constraint (ISC) method, and use this method to find optimal solutions to problems previously presented in the literature

references.title: Reliability optimization of coherent systems

context.text: System reliability problems can often be formulated as nonlinear integer programming problems which aim to maximize system reliability subject to several constraints [1]–[3].

links.abstract: This paper presents a search method based on lexicographic order, and an upper bound on the objective function, for solving redundancy allocation problems in coherent systems. Such problems generally belong to the class of nonlinear integer programming problems with separable constraints and nondecreasing functions. For illustration, 3 types of problems are solved using our method. Numerical investigation shows the performance of the method for large problems.

references.text: V. R. Prasad, W. Kuo, "Reliability optimization of coherent systems", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 49, pp. 323-330, 2000.

references.title: An annotated overview of system-reliability optimization

context.text: System reliability problems can often be formulated as nonlinear integer programming problems which aim to maximize system reliability subject to several constraints [1]–[2][3].

links.abstract: This paper provides: an overview of the methods that have been developed since 1977 for solving various reliability optimization problems; applications of these methods to various types of design problems; and heuristics, metaheuristic algorithms, exact methods, reliability-redundancy allocation, multi-objective optimization and assignment of interchangeable components in reliability systems. Like other applications, exact solutions for reliability optimization problems are not necessarily desir...

references.text: W. Kuo, V. R. Prasad, "An annotated overview of system-reliability optimization", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 49, pp. 176-187, 2000.

references.title:
Reliability optimization of series-parallel
systems using a genetic algorithm

context.text: System reliability problems can often be formulated as nonlinear integer programming problems which aim to maximize system reliability subject to several constraints [1]–[3].
Coit & Smith [3] proposed the “redundancy allocation problems with a mix of components” where components can be mixed within subsystems in a series-parallel system.

To obtain high quality solutions to the problem with a mix of components, some heuristic techniques have been proposed, e.g. genetic algorithm [3], [9], simulated annealing algorithm [10], and an ant colony optimization algorithm [12].

In this paper, we use the ISC method to solve redundancy allocation problems with a mix of components [3] that previously had not been solved exactly due to both the large solution space involved, and the surrogate duality gap.

links.abstract: A problem-specific genetic algorithm (GA) is developed and demonstrated to analyze series-parallel systems and to determine the optimal design configuration when there are multiple component choices available for each of several k-out-of-n:G subsystems. The problem is to select components and redundancy-levels to optimize some objective function, given system-level constraints on reliability, cost, and/or weight. Previous formulations of the problem have implicit restrictions concerning the type...

references.text: D. W. Coit, A. E. Smith, "Reliability optimization of series-parallel systems using a genetic algorithm", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 45, pp. 254-260, 1996.

references.title:
System reliability allocation and a computation
algorithm

context.text: [4] formulated redundancy allocation problems without component mixing, and solved these problems by using dynamic programming.
[4] solved the problem where \$n=14\$, and \$m=4\$.

Nakagawa & Miyazaki [5] made 33 test problems, based on those in [4], by varying the available weight \$(W)\$ from 159 to 191 while fixing the available cost \$(C=130)\$, and the number of units of \$k_{i}\$ \$(1\leq d_{i}\leq 5)\$.
If we consider Fyffe's problem [4] as the redundancy allocation problem with a mix of components, the problem is represented as [8], [9], [12] .

links.abstract: The detailed allocation method of system reliability discussed in this paper is designed to select the optimal solution in the context of the trade-off analysis. It is noted that the problem may be structured as an n-stage sequential decision problem. A computational algorithm is developed using dynamic programming.

references.text: D. E. Fyffe, W. W. Hines, N. K. Lee, "System reliability allocation and a computation algorithm", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. R-17, pp. 64-69, 1968.

references.title:
Surrogate constraints algorithm for reliability
optimization problems with two constraints

context.text: Nakagawa & Miyazaki [5] solved 33 problems, based on Fyffe's problems, by using a surrogate constraint method (N&M method).

Nakagawa & Miyazaki [5] made 33 test problems, based on those in [4], by varying the available weight \$(W)\$ from 159 to 191 while fixing the available cost \$(C=130)\$, and the number of units of \$k_{i}\$ \$(1\leq d_{i}\leq 5)\$.

Some optimization techniques (Linear Approximation by Hsieh [8], Genetic Algorithm by Coit & Smith [9], Ant Colony Optimization Algorithm by Liang & Smith [12], Tabu Search by Kulturel-Konak et al. [28]) have recently been proposed for solving the 33 test problems, presented by Nakagawa & Miyazaki [5], and treated as the redundancy allocation problems with a mix of components.

links.abstract: This paper presents an algorithm (called the N&M algorithm) for solving pure-integer separable nonlinear programming problems with two constraints. The N&M algorithm uses surrogate constraints and solves a given problem by effectively generating values of surrogate multiplier (i.e., surrogate problems) and solving the surrogate problems. Examples show that the N&M algorithm is superior to dynamic programming using the Lagrange multiplier in terms of number of iterations and narrowness of gap.

references.text: Y. Nakagawa, S. Miyazaki, "Surrogate constraints algorithm for reliability optimization problems with two constraints", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. R-30, pp. 175-180, 1981.

references.title:
An improved surrogate constraints method
for separable nonlinear integer programming

context.text: Nakagawa [6] proposed the improved surrogate constraint (ISC) method that can close the surrogate duality gap, and hence obtain exact optimal solutions to the original problems.
To address this difficulty, Nakagawa [6] proposed an improved surrogate constraint (ISC) method which will obtain an exact optimal solution to the original problem.

references.text: Y. Nakagawa, "An improved surrogate constraints method for separable nonlinear integer programming", Journal of the Operations Research Society of Japan, vol. 46, pp. 145-163, 2003.

references.title:
The system reliability optimization problems
by using an improved surrogate constraint method

context.text: By using the ISC method, it is possible to find exact optimal solutions to system reliability allocation problems that previously had not been solved due to the existence of a surrogate duality gap [7].
The redundancy allocation problem without component mixing [7] allows a subsystem to be duplicated, but only with the same set of components.

The exact optimal solutions to these 3 problems have been obtained by using the improved surrogate constraint (ISC) method that can close the surrogate duality gaps, and exactly solve the original problems [7].

references.text: S. Kimura, R. J. W. James, J. Onishi, Y. Nakagawa, "The system reliability optimization problems by using an improved surrogate constraint method", Advanced Reliability Modeling Proceedings of the 2004 Asian International Workshop, pp. 261-268, 2004.

references.title:
A linear approximation for redundant reliability problems
with multiple component choices

context.text: If we consider Fyffe's problem [4] as the redundancy allocation problem with a mix of components, the problem is represented as [8], [9], [12] .

Some optimization techniques (Linear Approximation by Hsieh [8], Genetic Algorithm by Coit & Smith [9], Ant Colony Optimization Algorithm by Liang & Smith [12], Tabu Search by Kulturel-Konak et al. [28]) have recently been proposed for solving the 33 test problems, presented by Nakagawa & Miyazaki [5], and treated as the redundancy allocation problems with a mix of components.

Table III shows the exact optimal reliability obtained by using the ISC method; and CPU times and the reliabilities obtained by using the methods proposed by Hsieh [8], Coit & Smith [9], Liang & Smith [12], and Kulturel-Konak et al. [28].

references.text: Y. Hsieh, "A linear approximation for redundant reliability problems with multiple component choices", Computers and Industrial Engineering, vol. 44, pp. 91-103, 2002.

references.title:
Penalty guided genetic search for reliability
design optimization

context.text: To obtain high quality solutions to the problem with a mix of components, some heuristic techniques have been proposed, e.g. genetic algorithm [3], [9], simulated annealing algorithm [10], and an ant colony optimization algorithm [12].
If we consider Fyffe's problem [4] as the redundancy allocation problem with a mix of components, the problem is represented as [8], [9], [12] .

Some optimization techniques (Linear Approximation by Hsieh [8], Genetic Algorithm by Coit & Smith [9], Ant Colony Optimization Algorithm by Liang & Smith [12], Tabu Search by Kulturel-Konak et al. [28]) have recently been proposed for solving the 33 test problems, presented by Nakagawa & Miyazaki [5], and treated as the redundancy allocation problems with a mix of components.
Because the size of the search spaces of these problems is larger than \$7.6 \times 10^{33}\$ [9], [12], it is very difficult to obtain exact optimal solutions to these problems.

Table III shows the exact optimal reliability obtained by using the ISC method; and CPU times and the reliabilities obtained by using the methods proposed by Hsieh [8], Coit & Smith [9], Liang & Smith [12], and Kulturel-Konak et al. [28].

references.text: D. W. Coit, A. E. Smith, "Penalty guided genetic search for reliability design optimization", Computers and Industrial Engineering, vol. 30, pp. 895-904, 1996.

annealing algorithm for redundancy optimization with multiple component choices

references.title: Studies on Optimal Design of High Reliability System: Single and Multiple Objective Nonlinear Integer Programming

context.text: If several alternatives with different attributes are available in each subsystem, either by using more reliable components or by providing redundant components in parallel, the optimization problem of system design can be formulated as a nonlinear integer programming problem [11].

references.text: Y. Nakagawa, Studies on Optimal Design of High Reliability System: Single and Multiple Objective Nonlinear Integer Programming, 1978, Kyoto University.

references.title:
An ant colony optimization algorithm for the redundancy
allocation problem (RAP)

context.text: To obtain high quality solutions to the problem with a mix of components, some heuristic techniques have been proposed, e.g. genetic algorithm [3], [9], simulated annealing algorithm [10], and an ant colony optimization algorithm [12].
If we consider Fyffe's problem [4] as the redundancy allocation problem with a mix of components, the problem is represented as [8], [9], [12] .

Some optimization techniques (Linear Approximation by Hsieh [8], Genetic Algorithm by Coit & Smith [9], Ant Colony Optimization Algorithm by Liang & Smith [12], Tabu Search by Kulturel-Konak et al. [28]) have recently been proposed for solving the 33 test problems, presented by Nakagawa & Miyazaki [5], and treated as the redundancy allocation problems with a mix of components.
Because the size of the search spaces of these problems is larger than \$7.6 \times 10^{33}\$ [9], [12], it is very difficult to obtain exact optimal solutions to these problems.

Table III shows the exact optimal reliability obtained by using the ISC method; and CPU times and the reliabilities obtained by using the methods proposed by Hsieh [8], Coit & Smith [9], Liang & Smith [12], and Kulturel-Konak et al. [28].
We found exact optimal solutions for all 33 test problems, including both the nine problems in [12], and the seven problems in [28] that previously had not be solved exactly.

links.abstract: This paper uses an ant colony meta-heuristic optimization method to solve the redundancy allocation problem (RAP). The RAP is a well known NP-hard problem which has been the subject of much prior work, generally in a restricted form where each subsystem must consist of identical components in parallel to make computations tractable. Meta-heuristic methods overcome this limitation, and offer a practical way to solve large instances of the relaxed RAP where different components can be placed in pa...

references.text: Y.-C. Liang, A. Smith, "An ant colony optimization algorithm for the redundancy allocation problem (RAP)", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 53, pp. 417-423, 2004.

Surrogate constraint techniques are known to be very effective in solving the nonlinear integer programming problem with multiple constraints [13].

references.text: M. E. Dyer, "Calculating surrogate constraints", Mathematical Programming, vol. 19, pp. 255-278, 1980.

Reliability optimization with multiple properties
and integer variables

context.text: To close the surrogate duality gap, consider the target problem \$[{\rm P}^{\rm T}(f^{\rm T},{\bf u}^{\ast})]\$ (Nakagawa & Hattori [17], and Miyaji et al. [23]).

The target problem \$[{\rm P}^{\rm T}(f^{\rm T},{\bf u}^{\ast})]\$ is the problem that enumerates all solutions satisfying the constraints of the original problem, and having the objective function values greater than a target value \$f^{\rm T}\$ [17].

links.abstract: The paper considers the problem of determining an optimal design of a reliability system with multiple properties and integer variables. This problem is formulated as a multiobjective nonlinear pure-integer programming problem. The method for solving this problem consists of three techniques: 1) narrowing a given feasible region if the region is too wide, 2) obtaining exactly the set of Pareto-optimal solutions, and 3) selecting the best one for decision makers from the set of Pareto-optimal sol...

references.text: Y. Nakagawa, Y. Hattori, "Reliability optimization with multiple properties and integer variables", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. R-28, pp. 73-78, 1979.

links.abstract: The paper presents a method for obtaining an optimal reliability allocation of an n-stage series system. In each stage, redundant comnponents can be added (in parallel, stand-by, or k-out-of-n:G, etc.), or a more reliable component can be used in order to improve the system reliability. The solution is obtained by repeatedly using a more reliable candidate at each stage that has the greatest value of a `weighted sensitivity function'. The balance between the objective unction and the constraints...

references.text: Y. Nakagawa, K. Nakashima, "A heuristic method for determining optimal reliability allocation", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. R-26, pp. 156-161, 1977.

links.abstract: This paper discusses allocating redundant components subject to resource constraints so as to optimize some measure of system performance. Two new exact algorithms are presented for the case where the objective and constraint functions are stagewise separable. Both are branch and bound algorithms. The first, BLE1, is based on an underlying knapsack structure, while the second, BLE2, exploits a multiple-choice knapsack structure. BLE1 can solve problems with 100 stages and 10 constraints in just ...

references.text: R. L. Bulfin, C. Y. Liu, "Optimal allocation of redundant components for large systems", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. R-34, pp. 241-247, 1985.
